tweets.text: @Jollyanna7 @agricontract @EnvAgency The people who gave permission to build should be compensating the people in the cottages and building joined up water planning.

We understand residents in Fishlake will be extremely anxious but we have been reassured by @EnvAgency that they are continuously monitoring the situation and don‚Äôt expect to issue any Flood Warnings, nor expect any properties to be affected, as river levels are starting to drop.

The weather has improved, but river levels are still high and @EnvAgency Flood Alerts remain in place in some parts of the River Don (Kirk Bramwith, Stainforth and Fishlake). 

The River Don continues to over-top near Stainforth spilling into wash lands, as it is designed to do. https://t.co/vvaAdFyb40

urls.title: The Prime Minister visits Didsbury following Storm Christoph
urls.description: This week, Storm Christoph brought heavy rain to very wet ground and full rivers. Today, I joined the Prime Minister who visited Didsbury in Greater Manchester where properties were evacuated. When we arrived the channel leading to the flood storage ‚Ä¶

tweets.text:
.@EmmaHowardBoyd accompanied the Prime Minister on a visit to #Didsbury today following #StormChristoph, to see how #TeamEA is working with emergency services and local government to protect against flooding.

Read her blog on the operational response: https://t.co/IojoGlCzXo https://t.co/WJhY9kXgfH

My thoughts are with those who've sadly already been affected by #StormChristoph and the flooding this week.

Each flooded home and business is a personal tragedy, and the @EnvAgency will keep working for as long as it takes to help those communities recover.

urls.title: Tories ignored expert flood advice and courted austerity. Behold the results | Simon Wren-Lewis
urls.description: The Pitt review predicted the current crisis in 2008, but the report was overlooked. Now the devastating results of this are clear, says professor of economics Simon Wren-Lewis
